Rough Green Snake PBL Piney

Rough Green Snake PBL Woods

Citations ecosystem proposal design time

Snake PBL

Everthing by: Adan Sanchez

Introduction:

Hi This is brought to you by group 6. We took inn to consideration of how the teachers said to try different methods on presenting. We Chose to use the eco-region Piney Woods.

Opheodrys aestivus

Rough green snakes are non-venomous, relatively non aggressive organisms that rarely bite, and normally don’t mind being in close proximity to humans. They have a life span for about 15 years. The rough green snakes eat crickets, grasshoppers, spiders, small frogs, and caterpillars.

The environment

The Piney Woods has a warm and humid climate with around 50in of rain per year. The piney woods are moist, lush, thick, vegetated areas. With many different types of trees, bushes, and other plant. Piney woods have ponds, and little streams everywhere.

The Building process

We got a glass terrarium, and put soil in, to be exact we put 0.25Ft3 which was ⅓ of the bag, then planted grass as a food source and foliage. We then put a heat lamp in it to make it hot, and moist. We added sticks, stones, and lots of dead leaves. After that we added crickets.

Behavior

Rough Green Snakes are diurnal meaning they are active in the day instead of night and are arboreal which means they live in trees.

Biotic and Abiotic factors

Biotic factors include:

-Sundews -Magnolia -Ivy -Water Moccasin -Frogs -A variety of birds and Insects

Abiotic factors include:

-Water -Sticks -Rocks -Soil -Sunlight -Humidity -Wind currents

Challenges we faced

Sustainable water

We couldn’t get the water to sustain and we got a water pump but it didn't work the way we envisioned.

Sustainable food

We were trying to find a food source that could reproduce asexualy. Eventually we found out that earth worms could, but we didn't bring them.

Lid

We needed a lid that could fit the aquarium and let air and water in. We also needed a place for our heat lamp to go, but we couldn’t figure out a good angle.

Getting the snake to soon

We misunderstood what we were told about the snake, and ended up ordering it too soon. Though being able to sustain grass and crickets, our ecosystem could not sustain a snake.

Soil Amount

We needed to find cubic meters and so we turned inches into cubic meters to measure how much soil we needed for our enclosure, so to find cubic meters we need to find the height, width and how much soil we need, we then can turn our inches into Ft, So we had 20 Inches (L) 10 ½ inches (W) 2 inches (H) we then divided all of them by 12 getting us 1.6 Ft(L) 0.875 Ft(W) and 0.16 Ft(H) The bag of soil was 0.75 cubic ft of soil 0.23 cubic ft ≈ 0.25ft3

Necessities

They need foliage such as sticks, leaves, vines and such as they do like to hide in there enclosure, It will also most likely need lots of branches and vines as they don’t really come down unless its to drink water or eat food, If handled regularly it will become use to you but handling it to much will stress it out, It is just better to leave them alone as its better for them to just be left in there enclosure. They need lots of water so having a big pool of water is a good idea, They also primarily eat bugs such as caterpillars, moths, crickets, grasshoppers, Etc.

Summary:

The organism is the Rough Green Snake. The eco-region is the piney woods. The snake is okay in 80 to 85 degrees fahrenheit, but perfer to bask in 90 degrees. The snake can eat crickets and worms (earth and meal worms) the food chain would look like Sun, Grass, Crickets, Snake, Then worms. The worms can be eaten by the snake but the worms are considered as decomposers. Though the habitat was untested due to the snake having to be sent back.

Brave. Bold. Fearless.
